@InvsbleFriends 11/ But also the opposite can be true if the estimate at hand requires A LOT of specialized knowledge, which is why I report also the estimate of the 'mini-crowd'. So, do you want to contribute? üëá

@InvsbleFriends 10/ we'll see what happens next on Feb 24th we'll know for sure how off we were. One of the ways we could have messed this up: we had only 32 participants to the poll. ...And Science tells us that estimates get more accurate with large crowds.

@InvsbleFriends 9/ This is very far from my personal estimate, standing at 7.3 eth on launch day. Similarly, the estimate of what I consider the best analysts in the community, stands at around 6.7 eth. This can be considered as a 'mini-crowd of experts'.
@InvsbleFriends 8/ so for the price point of Invsblefriends. The community at large says 4.9 eth as the avg price on the first trading day.

@InvsbleFriends 7/ Enter: Blockgems, the community based on social signal tools and wisdom of the crowd. We track discord members, tt followers and tt mentions for each target project in the pre-launch phase. then we poll the community knowledge to get a price point.
@InvsbleFriends 6/ but what happens when market dynamics are unable to arise because the project is in the pre-launch / 'hype' phase? How can we guess the price of the project 'pre-market'?

@InvsbleFriends 5/ What does this have to do with NFTs? well, the market, even the NFT market, is a form of collective intelligence. Whenever market dynamics take place we can get a sense of the value (i.e. the price) of a project.

@InvsbleFriends 4/ in the popular tv show 'who wants to be a millionaire' the 'experts' (‚Äì i.e. the players) got the questions right 65% of the time, whereas the audience (‚Äìfolks that apparently have nothing better to do that sitting in a TV studio) got it right 91% of the time.
@InvsbleFriends 3/ In 1907 Sir Francis Galton asked a crowd to estimate the weight of an ox. the avg of all the individual estimates was just 1 pound away from the actual weight of the animal.
@InvsbleFriends 2/ I was always fascinated by the topic of collective intelligence. The idea that seemingly dumb crowds can be smarter than individual 'experts'.

What will be the avg trading price of @InvsbleFriends on the day of launch?

You can provide your estimate below, but if you are interested in what our community has estimated + the how and why, then read on üßµ

The project can grow much more in price, but IMO not in the immediate short term. In the long term, it‚Äôs a fantastic play, but you‚Äôd have to have a 1 year time horizon to enter now. This is contrarian ofc as everyone is bullish @nftworldsNFT  but‚Ä¶

9/If you find the above informative, join us, we have crazy good social signals for NFTs . ... while it's free, and the free access won‚Äôt be open for long: https://t.co/VyWqK2Zoq4
8/ It is by all means a contrarian play as you are betting with the pack knowing that you'll have to change strategy at peak sentiment.
7/ In all honesty, often I did buy pre-reveal, but I have also sold most often pre reveal. namely into the hype that leads into showtime. The excitement prior that moment.

6/ The collection owners have all the incentives to hype it up to the max pre reveal, but you know how it is 'buy the rumors sell the news'. This is based on the fact that the true news/reveal hardly ever satisfies expectations.
5/ Also, it is only post reveal that you see if the art had problems, think mekaverse, hapebeast, this stuff was largely disappointing when it came to artistic uniqueness and consistency in quality.

4/ likewise people still buy the pre-reveal token in the hopes they'll get a rare but truth is the odds are against you. Even if people were not overly optimistic as they are, price will still have to drop.
3/ When you bet on red on the Roulette, you have 18 / 38 chances of success (american roulette, 0 and 00) and you get paid 2 to 1. Unfair game. totally irrational, people still play it.
2/ And truth is, people suck at being good intuitive statisticians and in making probabilistic assessments. Think Casinos, slot machines and lotteries, they all thrive on this mental glitch we have.

Why is it more often than not a bad idea to buy an NFT pre-reveal when you are close to show time, üßµ:

1/ Many NFTs  drop in floor price post reveal. Firstly, why  is it so?

In the price of the pre-reveal token you have to factor in people's expectations of getting a rare.
